snippet: Largely excluded from the economic recovery, carpenters, electricians, plumbers and other construction workers are pleading for work on the online classified advertising site.
abstract: Carpenters, electricians, plumbers and other construction workers, largely excluded from the economic recovery, are advertising for work on the online classified advertising site Craigslist; builders are not hiring, homeowners are deferring renovations and governments are postponing highway and bridge projects, leaving few options; economists are forecasting that the nation's employers added about 165,000 net jobs last month, but few of them are in the construction industry. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: With few places to turn, construction workers have colonized Craigslist as the cyberspace equivalent of the street corner or the Home Depot parking lot. Some are getting more than they bargained for as they search for ad hoc jobs. One Palm Beach man who previously worked on crews renovating Walmart stores agreed to clean out an apartment after a tenant committed suicide. But he drew the line at hanging up a sex swing.

headline.main: For Craftsmen, Fragile Lifeline From Craigslist
